DIV1.P: As it is Performed at the THEATRE-ROYAL, BY His MAJESTY's Servants.
By Mr. CHETWOOD, Prompter to the Theatre.

Q.L: He will his Safety to his Weakness Owe,
As Grass escapes the Scythe by being low. Macbeth.

DIV1.P: LONDON: Printed: And Sold by A. DODD, at the Peacock without Temple-Bar. MDCCXXIX. [Price One Shilling.]

DIV1.HEAD: PREFACE.
DIV1.P: I Should hardly have given the Reader the Trouble of a Preface, were it not to pay my Acknow∣ledgment to the kind Performers, who, notwithstanding the Hazard of being discountenanc'd, are yet so good-natur'd once more to venture in this Dangerous Road, purely with the friendly Desire of assisting my Interest.

We all join'd in this Belief, That I was below the Notice of the Criticks, and therefore hop'd I might escape their Cen∣sure. I own, Poetry is a thing I little un∣derstand; yet should I meet a better Fate than possibly I may deserve, I shall grate∣fully acknowledge my self oblig'd to the
generous Town for their Indulgence, but never arrogate to my self any Merit thereon.

This Attempt being begun soon after the Run of the Celebrated Beggar's Opera (to mention which gives me some Confu∣sion, while I am speaking of my own weak Endeavours) the Reader may perhaps find some few Tunes since made use of in other Entertainments of this Kind. I must de∣clare the Songs thereto were made before I ever saw any such Performances—and had Leisure permitted me, I had alter'd 'em —Such as it is, I throw it on the Mercy of its Auditors.

DIV1.HEAD: PROLOGUE.
DIV1.L: OUR humble Bard (well he deserves that Name,
Who from the Muse no borrow'd Aid can claim;)
Seeing your modern Opera's spring so thick,
Thought Sing-song easie as a Juggler's Trick.
Building on This, and conscious of no Skill,
He gives You his Assay, of pure good Will.
Since he pleads guilty, wink at one Offence:
Mercy has oft reclaim'd to sober Sense.
He likes the Trade so ill, as a Beginner,
He swears, he ne'er shall grow a harden'd Sinner:
Unless—Heav'n help him! — Wit should turn his Brain;
Then—look for Hurlothrumbo's once again;
Then look—to see him ride the Moon,—and dance,—
And fiddle to his own Extravagance.
Tho',—should That happen, he might plead some Merit;
What once was Madness, now is Wit and Spirit.
But, yet, poor Soul! he claims not that proud Bays,
You'll understand him,—tho' you should not praise.
For Those whose doubtful Fate it is to be
The Organs of his chaunted Poetry,
Tho' Him you censure, think, They barely do
Nor more, nor less, than what He prompts 'em to.
Then, 'faith, be kind;—you've had your Treat of Wit;
And He would needs throw in his gratis Bit.
Like a frank Host, that, when the Reck'ning's o'er,
Brings up his Flask, adds Nothing to your Score.

DIV1.HEAD: Dramatis Personae.
The LOVER'S Opera.

DIV2.HEAD: SCENE I. A Hall.
DIV2.STAGE: Dalton perusing Papers; Lucy observing at distance.

SP.SPEAKER: DALTON.
SP.P: SURE now these Daughters of mine can have no Pretence to charge me with Se∣verity; I have with the utmost Care and Diligence provided Husbands for 'em both.
If they do but like the Provision you have made, 'twill be very well. Aside.

Their deceased Uncle has (out of my Power, foolish Man for so doing) given each of them a separate Fortune of Ten thousand Pounds — the Interest of which I have taken care to account for in the Articles of Education, Necessaries, and so forth.
I don't question it. Aside.

Now what remains to be done is to make as sure of some of the Principal, if I can—but that they will Command when of Age, or, what's worse, on the day of Marriage, which Misfortune I must guard against—Oh what a Plague it is to a Man to have the Care of two Buxom Girls past their Teens!
AIR I. Diogenes surly and proud.
Our Children for Blessings were meant,
Yet seldom a Blessing they prove;
They poison a Parent's Content.
With Plagues in their obstinate Love.
In Nonage they whimper and cry,
And teize us all Day with their Noise;
In their Teens they our Projects destroy,
And, sighing for Man, kill our Joys.
These Gentlemen are, for my Authority, Interest, and Approbation in the Affair, to give me each two thousand Pound, and this they have oblig'd themselves under Hand and Seal to perform.
Have they so?
How now Saucebox! what Business have you here?
What Business have I any where else? Am I not serving my Mistresses? doing my Duty? while you are plotting to sacrifice 'em to your own rapacious Avarice.
This Wench has overheard me, and I cou'd find in my, Heart to murder the Jade.
Say you so! but I'll take Care first to blow up your Scheme; I'll go immediately, and give Infor∣mation of ev'ry Particular to—
I had better close with her—Hussy, come hither.
I won't.
Come hither, I say.
I won't, I say.
I wou'd talk with thee—Thou art the Cabi∣net of both my Daughters Secrets, and I have a Desire to trust thee—Is it possible, any way in the World to make thee my Friend?
No.
Suppose I shou'd make it thy Interest to be so?
Humh! what's he about?—You can't.
Why not?
You have not Generosity enough.
Try me.
Shall I?
Do—I'll give thee in the first Place a— a Guinea.
Pugh—one young Lover of my Ladies wou'd have brib'd me with ten times the Sum.
But Lucy—when my Daughters are dispos'd of— ha! I have no more Children, and may—
What, pray?
I may—perhaps take thee to warm—my Bed—be my Housekeeper—you understand me.
Yes I do, but I won't.

DIV1.HEAD: AIR II. Red House.
DIV1.L: Youth and Age will never
Well agree together,
But with stormy Weather
Pass the long and tedious Day.
Age with Clouds will cover,
Damp, and kill the Lover;
'Tis the Youthful Rover
Proves our lively shining Ray.
This Age and Youth
Are Lies and Truth,
They differ more than Peace and War.
They're Heat and Cold,
They're Lead and Gold,
They're Debtors that have nought to pay.

SP.P: What is it I can do to please thee?
Why—if as a Specimen of what you dare do, you wou'd give me ten Pieces.
Ten! Ten!
Ay Ten!
Why thou art a Jew—but Lucy, tell me first—
No, the Fee first, or not a tittle of Advice.
Give—Give—I'll—I'll—
Come, give me five.
Poh five!
But what am I doing? I am going to betray two innocent young Ladies to—
Thy own Interest, think of that—Come, I will give thee five.
Let me consider—Suppose I shou'd take the Money, and deceive the old Knave himself. Aside.
Ay, do, consider on't.
I am not the first Advocate who has taken Fees on both Sides.
No, no, nor won't be the last.
Well Sir, name your Conditions.
You are, in the first Place, to discover to me the Amours, Intrigues, &c. of your young Mistresses.
Well!
If any Letters are put into your Hands by them, or for 'em, you are to deliver 'em to me.
Well, well!
And this you promise.
Upon Condition.
Ay, upon Condition you have five Guineas— there they are.

This Money is—in short, what is it not? it's Wisdom, Honour, all! but Honesty. This is the Lovers Darts and Flames,
The Rosy Cheek, the Brilliant Eyes,
The panting Heart, and heaving Sighs.

DIV1.HEAD: AIR III. Mad Robin.
DIV1.L: This gives Females Wit and Charms,
The Force of this will Virtue prove,
This will fill old Bromia's Arms,
With this She buys her Love.
'Tis Gold will gain the Knave a Place,
Tho' Merit pleads in vain:
'Twill wipe away the worst Disgrace,
And soften Love's Disdain.

SP.P: But tell me, Child, dost think the Inclinations of both these Girls are fixt?
I am afraid so.
On whom?
Why Clara loves Mr. Edgar, that's certain.
And he her?
Yes.
Young Moody—but it seems there's a De∣mur on his Side—he's lately more inclin'd to Clara too.
What, are Edgar and he Rivals?
I fancy so, for Flora is in Tears about it.
I am glad on't—but can't we contrive to set 'em a fighting?
Ay! but suppose one of 'em shou'd be run thro'?
Why then t'other wou'd be hang'd, and so we're rid of 'em both.
A good Conscience, by my troth—But pray Sir, who are these Lovers you have provided for these young Ladies, that I may be able to serve them, and you, when Occasion offers?
I'll tell thee—one of 'em is my good Friend and Fellow-Citizen, Mr. Aminidab Prim.
What, the Quaker?
He's rich.
Is he not too old?
He's rich, very rich.
Flora, or either of 'em—the next is Captain Clotpole.
Ah Lord! why he's a Fool.
Rich, rich, very rich, and he talks of Clara.
Or either of 'em.
Ay, ay, ay—but in case one of these shou'd not please, I have provided one fine Gentleman.
Ay! who is he?
Monsieur Varole.

SP.L: O my Stars! why he is heartily ugly, and—

SP.P: A Beau, that you'll confess.
And rich, I suppose.
Right! and consents to give me Two thou∣sand Pounds to make the Match.

Ay, ay, that Consideration outweighs all the rest—besides, I don't see but all Men are alike, when once they commence Husbands—not one in ten proves worth half the Trouble we give our selves about 'em.
I fancy 'tis much the same with your Sex.
Ay, much the same, much the same indeed, Sir.

DIV1.HEAD: AIR IV. Mother, quoth Hodge.
DIV1.L: Tho' Couples are fond when first they are wed,
Their Passions decline as oft as they meet.
Before a full Month their Love is all fled,
With Spleen and cold Looks each other they greet.
They're both the same:
Love's but a Name.

SP.L: Then Women Experiments ne'er shou'd try:
Their Hearts ever giving their Tongue the Lye.

SP.P: And now, Sir, to shew you how much I am yours, you must know Clara and Edgar are got toge∣ther in the Garden, by her Appointment—If you have a mind to spoil their Assignation, there you'll find 'em—Tho' I hope he's gone by this time.
I'll do't; mean while you'll be diligent.

And secret, you may depend on't. [Exit Dal.] I cannot find one Scruple of Conscience in over-reach∣ing this old Curmudgeon—besides, I find it my In∣terest —my young Lovers are too generous not to re∣ward me, if I succeed; and that Reward may help me to a Husband—for few Men, now-a-days, care to take a Woman with nothing.

DIV1.HEAD: AIR V. Buff-Coat.
DIV1.L: Poor Marriage of late,
Like Places of State,
Without Money will find no Favour.
Is there Money, you cry?
If no; they reply,
The Devil himself may have her.
If you have a good Purse,
For better for worse
The Men will all strive to take you.
But of that if you fail,
You'll never prevail,
For the Wretches will all forsake you. Exit.

SP.P:
How unjust it is in Parents to be ever indulg∣ing their own Passions and Desires, and never once consult their Childrens Happiness; no, not in that only Particular that must make 'em happy or mi∣serable —I mean that Union which must last for Life.
AIR VI. When the Kine had giv'n a Pailful.
If we feel a tender Passion,
Parents cry we're much to blame.
Loving now is out of Fashion,
Interest is their only Aim.
Wretched Creatures!
'Tis their Natures:
When with Age the Blood runs cold,
Love's call'd Folly,
Melancholy:
All their Longings are for Gold.
All their, &c.
What should make Edgar stay so long—I hope my hated Lover Moody has not met with him—no, he's here.
My Love!

My Clara!
AIR VII. When Sol did cast no Light.
Why weeps my lovely Fair?
O cease this Sorrow!
Fly hence, Intruding Care:
Some Comfort borrow.
O still this troubled Breast!
I'll bear thy Anguish:
Love will restore our Rest;
No more we'll languish.
Thy Father's Temper yet may change, and we be happy.
I hope the best▪ But Hope, alas! too fre∣quently is the worst of Flatterers.

DIV1.HEAD: AIR VIII. My Days have been so wond'rous free.

SP.L: 'Tis Hope that sweetens Want and Woe,
The shackled Slave can Grief forego,
Hope is the Cure of black Despair,
We sighing hope to gain the Fair,

SP.P: I'll hope the best, and be as cheerful as I can; but let what will come, be assur'd, I'll never change my Love.

DIV1.HEAD: AIR IX. Dee'l take the Wars.

LG.L: The cheering Sun shall cease his shining,
If Clara e'er proves false to thee;
No slighted Lover know repining,
Or Tempest ever shake the Sea.
The smiling Spring shall cease her Blooming;
The rapid Stream no more shall flow;
The warbling Birds forget their Pluming,
Or vernal Roses cease to blow.
No Mortal e'er shall move me;
I'll shun all (but thee) that love me,
All Slighting, all Scorning, for thee, my Swain.
All Tortures I will bear
For thee, my only Dear:
Do thou prove true,
As I will be to you,
And Clara e'er will find a Joy in Pain.

DIV1.HEAD: AIR X. Sweet Nelly, my Heart's Delight.

SP.L: If e'er I prove false to thee,
The Lawyer shall slight his Fee;
For ever I will be thine.

DIV1.HEAD: AIR XI. Make your Honours, Miss.

SP.L: Will you be gone, Sir? tol, lol. to Edgar.
I'll swinge you anon, Sir, tol, lol. to Clara.
Zouns, what's your Business here? tol, lol. to Edgar.
You'll smart for this, my Dear. tol, lol. to Clara.

SP.P: Dear Sir, be not angry, but consider.
So I will consider—but it shall be to rid my House of this prowling Puppy; I'll have him out of my Fold, for fear of thee, my little Lamb— Where are all my Rogues and Whores?
Seize this Fellow, carry him to the Devil, and leave him there; and you Mrs. Minx, see your Mi∣stress into her Chamber, and d'ye hear, lock her up.

DIV1.HEAD: AIR XII. Celia, that I once was blest.

SP.L: If he leaves me, Joy and Rest
Will fly for ever from my Breast;
If thou'rt banisht from these Eyes;
Thou alone canst only bless me;

DIV1.HEAD: AIR XIII. To you fair Ladies now on Land.

SP.L: Thus frighted Saliors view the Skies,
With heaving Sighs, and watry Eyes,
No Hope, alas, of Life they have:
The Wreck becomes a watry Grave,
They sink, to rise no more. Forc'd off.

SP.P: Away with 'em—I was exceeding Fortu∣nate to prevail on this Maid of hers—She will be of vast Service to me, in the Management of my De∣sign. —Who's that? Mr. Clotpole?

Your Servant, Father-in-Law, that should be, I mean—but how it will be brought about, Egad, I am at a loss to imagine—I met your Daughter here, and she flounc'd from me, as if I had been a Hobgoblin—I call'd her my Love, my Dear— No, says she, I would sooner wander thro' the World in Misery and Shame. And I am sure if she does, let her set out when she will, I must follow her,
for I have lost my Rest and my Stomach for Love of her, and am almost out of my Wits already about her.

DIV1.HEAD: AIR XIV. Bartholomew Fair.
DIV1.L: This Love is the Deel, the Source of all Ill;
I burn and I freeze together,
I sob and I sigh, I live and I dye,
Like Wasps half drown'd in hot Weather.
The Frost of her Charms my Reason disarms,
The Fire of her Eyes destroy;
I'll hang, or I'll drown, or Ratsbane gulp down,
If Clara I cannot enjoy.

SP.P: I thought you had more Courage—you that are a Captain of the Militia, should know bet∣ter than to give over upon the first Repulse; attack her once more, advance but briskly, and depend on't she surrenders—and if she does not, I am Gover∣nor of the Fort, and will capitulate for her.
You advise well—Yet I can't but say I am somewhat doubtful, for ever since I saw her, my Heart does thump, thump, it beats like a Drum unbrac'd.
A proper Simile! but I will not have it so, I tell you.
Well then, go on, I'll follow you. Exit.

How arbitrary is Love? its Power, how absolute? My Heart is giv'n to Clara, and while she disdains the Present, Flora sighs for it in vain— would I could love her more, or Clara less! I fear it will not be; the more I strive, the more I'm intangl'd —my Passion when oppos'd, like Water thrown against the Wind, returns again with greater Vio∣lence.
AIR XV. Ye Nymphs and Sylvan Gods.
Love like a Torrent flows:
If we its Streams oppose,
We find to our Cost,
Our Reason is lost,
The Mind with Confusion grows.
Sure Love was first sent
To break our Content,
And kill our springing Joys.
How blest is he
From Love is free;
The fairest She
Shou'd slighted be,
Since Love all our Peace destroys.
Ha! my Rival! my hot Blood prompts me to revenge the Pain his Love creates me.
Enter Edgar. Edgar, draw.
Rash Man, consider.
Draw I say, and defend your Life. Clara will scorn a Coward.
You wrong me in that Imputation I dare your utmost. Disarms him.
Disarm'd! Shame and Confusion!
There, take your Life.
'Tis more than I deserve.
I know too well the Pain of Love, not to forgive the Frenzy it creates.

Generous Man! what shall I do? what say? to recompence such Virtue? This Action melts my Soul: I am convinc'd, my Passion is unjust: Clara is his of right; and why did I betray my former Love? Reason lights me to my Shame: Can you forgive, believe, and take me to your Friendship?
The Sense you have of what is past, convinces me I ought to do so.
I will endeavour to recall my Heart, that I may give it to the injur'd Flora, and wrong your Love no more.
Come to my Arms, my Friend!
My Brother!

DIV1.HEAD: AIR XVI. As the Snow in Valleys lying.
DIV1.L: Friendship, when the Mind's abounding,
With our gloomy Cares surrounding,
Helps to bear an equal Part.
Next to Love, 'tis all our Treasure,
Lightens Sorrow, doubles Pleasure,
Sympathizing in the Heart. Exeunt.

SP.P: Dear Sister, let's not abandon our selves thus to Grief; I have an equal Cause to mourn with you. Our Father may relent, and that will end your Cares; but mine must still continue; I love a Man that scorns my Passion.

DIV1.HEAD: AIR XVII. Whilst I gaz'd on Chloe trembling.
DIV1.L: Ah cruel Love, lay by thy Quiver,
Nor so deeply plunge thy Dart;
In vain I burn for the Deceiver,
Whose killing Eyes have pierc'd my Heart.
While I sigh for this Ungrateful,
Cupid, give my Mind some Ease;
Life to me will soon grow hateful,
When I can no longer please.

SP.P:
My Dear, 'tis possible my Contempt of Moody may make him again change his Mind, and pursue his first Love to you—but Parents Avarice is a Disease that strengthens with Age, and knows no Cure.
AIR XVIII. 'Twas within a Furlong, &c.
When sordid Love of Coin within the Mind is born,
It thrives in wintry Age like Glastenbury Thorn.
Other Passions fly away,
Like the Night before the Day.
'Tis Gold and Gain
Gives Joy and Pain;
To that they only pray.
This shining Earth creates all our Strife,
Imbitters all our Sweet, is the Sorrow of our Life.
Poor Love must shun the Light,
Or else be banisht quite,
For Money, Money, only Money is the World's Delight.
Have we no way to disappoint such mean, such unjust Practices?
For my Part, my Mind is so involv'd in Love, my Invention's lost: As Plants are cheer'd by the Sun, so the Heart of a Maid droops or revives by the Smiles or Frowns of the Person she loves.

DIV1.HEAD: AIR XIX. Fair Dorinda seated was.
DIV1.L: When Love a Woman's Heart has crost
There is no Room for Joys,
Our Mind's with various Fancies tost,
Love all our Thought employs.
The Flower, when cheer'd by Phoebus' Ray,
Will flourish, bloom, and rise;
But when the Night drives out the Day,
It withers, fades and dies.

SP.P: I have sent Lucy to Mr. Edgar to appoint ano∣ther Meeting this Evening, when the Eyes of our Argus will be clos'd in Sleep: You shall be with us, perhaps something may be thought of for our Relief.

DIV2.HEAD: SCENE V. A Room in Edgar's House.

SP.P: How slowly Time advances, when Expectation is on the Wing to meet him! I have this Hour ex∣pected a Message from my Clara.
I am, like you, impatient to see my Love, and soften her Distress.

DIV1.HEAD: AIR XX. Love's a Dream of mighty Pleasure.

SP.L: How slow the tedious Moments pass,
But Time in haste will shake his Glass,
Too rigid Fate! you deal us Bliss,
But Care and Anguish you dismiss
Like creeping Snails, by moving slow.

SP.P: Here comes your Messenger of Peace.
Bless me! what do I see? Mr. Moody here!
Cease your Wonder, and let me satisfy you that Edgar and I are Friends, and that I will no longer injure the charming Flora, but throw my self at her Feet for Pardon.
You may obtain it, I believe: but you have both greater Difficulties to encounter.
I'm on the Rack!—What are they?
What are they? why Dragons, Hydras: Their old Rogue of a Father has been providing Hus∣bands for both my young Mistresses, and to-morrow Morning they're to be joined in Wedlock.
Impossible! Clara will never yield to such Injustice.
That's more than you know; Women are changeable: She has seen her new Lover since you parted with her, I can tell you that.
Why will you torture me?
She is determined not to oppose her Father's Will.
You wrong her.
Well, if I do, I do: but she bids me tell you so.
Are all her Vows and Protestations come to this?

DIV1.HEAD: AIR XXI. Tell me, tell me, charming Creature.
DIV1.L: Can she prove so false a Creature?
Are her Oaths and Vows but Wind?
Had she Charms in ev'ry Feature,
And for Ruin all design'd?

DIV1.HEAD: AIR XXII. All the World's in Strife and Hurry.
DIV1.L: O cruel Maid, to slight me!
I'll tear thee from my Breast.
No more thy Charms delight me,
But rob me of my Rest.

DIV1.HEAD: AIR XXIII. William and Margaret.
DIV1.L: But can my Soul forsake those Charms
Which Time has rooted here?
Or see her in another's Arms?
That Fate is too severe!

DIV1.HEAD: AIR XXIV. Jovial Beggar.

LG.L: Since she is false as fair,
The Syren I will shun;
No more her Chains I'll wear,
Nor sue to be undone.
And a roving I will go, will go, will go,
And a roving I will go.
To distant Climes I'll fly,
And never more return;
Her Charms I'll now defy,
Since vainly thus I burn.
And a roving I will go, will go, will go,
And a roving I will go.

SP.P:
I thank thee, and forgive this kind Deceit,
Lucy. But it is ill trifling with a sincere Lover.
Have you the Heart now to meet Mrs. Clara in her Chamber this Evening at Seven?
I wou'd meet her, tho' ten thousand Dangers bar my way.
But suppose you shou'd find a Parson there?
I shou'd look on him as my better Genius.
Do you think Mr. Moody will come too?
You wrong me to doubt it.
You'll be welcome, I believe: As yet I can give you only Hopes; but by the Time propos'd my Plot may be ripe, in all probability.
Pray Heaven it may succeed.

DIV1.HEAD: AIR XXVI. With tuneful Pipe, &c.
DIV1.L: O gentle Love, assist thy Swain
To gain this wisht-for Prize;
Grant me the Balm to heal the Pain
Created by her Eyes.
I sighing weep
Depriv'd of Sleep,
And sink with Woes opprest.
My Love restore,
I ask no more;
'Twill give me Joy,
My Cares destroy,
'Twill give me Joy and Rest.

SP.P: But Gentlemen, tho' I am in very great Haste to be gone, yet I can't part with you till I know how this happy Change has been wrought in Mr. Moody's Temper; and by what lucky Accident you are be∣come Friends.
While I am writing three Lines to the wrong'd Flora, Edgar shall inform you all.
You must be very speedy, for my old Master is impatient.
In the next Room is Pen, Ink, and Paper.

Do you dispatch your Letter, I'll follow you immediately.—A very ticklish Business have I un∣dertaken here. Well, they may talk of State Matters, but if there is not more Art in managing of such an Affair as I have taken in Hand, I'll be contented to die a Maid, and that's a Punishment in this World and the next.

DIV1.HEAD: AIR XXVII. We've cheated the Parson.
DIV1.L: The State of old Virgins is surely hard,
From all their soft Wishes to be debarr'd:
To sigh and whine,
To long and pine,
Sad Fate of a Maid—may it ne'er be mine.
The greatest Distress that have Maids befell,
Is that of the Curse to lead Apes in Hell,
Woeful Case,
Hard Disgrace!
'Tis worse than a Statesman when out of Place. Exit.

SP.P:
I will not have you thus eternally in the Pouts: Do you reflect upon the Duty you owe a Father? up∣on the many Obligations you have to me? Have you consider'd enough the Crime of a repeated Disobe∣dience? Do but this, and your Whimperings and Pas∣sions, and Fiddle-Faddles will disappear. Besides, I
expect ev'ry Hour those worthy Gentlemen I have made Choice of for your Husbands.
I cou'd wish, Sir, to know the Gentlemen, before an Affair of that Consequence is concluded— perhaps—
Look ye, look ye, I'll have none of your Perhaps, since you are ready for Husbands, you shall have 'em of my providing.

DIV1.HEAD: AIR XXVIII. In the Fields in Frost and Snow.
DIV1.L: When our Daughters Husbands want,
We must watch 'em nearly.
Then their Hearts will swell and pant,
Night and Morning early.
Sighing here,
Whining there,
Here a Sigh, there a Whine,
Every where a Whine.
O what Plague it is in Life,
'Till a Daughter's made a Wife!

SP.P: Do you see, these Husbands that I have provided for you are responsible Men, Men of Substance, Capaci∣ty, Judgment, Probity, Candor; Men that—! they are Men—In short, they are Men to my Mind, and they shall be so to yours.
If they shou'd not like our Persons, you wou'd not insist—
Once more, I command you to have done with your If's, and your Perhaps, I'll have none of 'em.
Lord bless me!
What now?
I am frighted out of my Senses.
What a Devil's the Matter with the Wench?
Yonder has been—Give me a little time to recover my Breath—Yonder has been a barbarous Murder done.
Where? when? by whom?
Mr. Edgar and Mr. Moody have been fighting a Duel.
And both dead, ha?
No, neither of 'em dead, but mortally woun∣ded to be sure.
Both?
Yes, both.
I'm glad on't.
O my Heart!
Unhappy Flora!

They happened to meet; Mr. Moody no sooner saw the other, but out he draws his Sword, and at it they went, like two—two—two Cocks in a Sawpit; but before any body cou'd interpose, each had done the other's Business.
What's become of 'em?
They're in Custody, and Surgeons sent for, but 'tis fear'd, to little purpose.
O Misery—this is the curst Jealousy of Moody.

DIV1.HEAD: AIR XXIX. Fond Echo.
DIV1.L: O Jealousy! Bane to our Joy,
Thou Thorn in the Rose-blooming Grove,
Why dost thou our Pleasure destroy,
And wound the fair Features of Love?
O Cupid, in Sorrow appear,
And mourn the sad Fate of a Maid,
With Hymen drop in a salt Tear;
False Honour my Love has betray'd.

SP.P: This was a fortunate Accident.
Ay, beyond Expectation for your Purpose.
But the Shock has so fluster'd the Girls they'll not be able to receive these Visitors with any decency; what shall we do?
I'll tell you—did not you promise me five Pieces more?
I wou'd not have thee so mercenary.
I shou'd be glad you were not so covetous.
When the Affair is brought to bear: In the mean time—there, there's a Guinea in Part: now what say'st thou?

Why I say—a Guinea is too little in Con∣science —Gold is such a vast help to Invention— but—I was thinking—now suppose I follow 'em, and persuade 'em this Duel was an Invention of my own, that you thinking 'em dead, might give your self no trouble in guarding against 'em—I know they'll never consent to marry the Men you propose, unless thus betray'd into the Marriage.
As how? as how?

I'll make my Mistresses believe that they are but slightly wounded, and will visit 'em in the Eve∣ning in the dark, for fear of you—It must be sup∣posed: —You shall send Clotpole and Prim in their laces, who shall carry Father Tatter Crape the Curate with 'em, to tack 'em together.
One of my Footmen shall go find him out and bring him. Mean while, prepare the Girls, as I will the Lovers. If we succeed not, we are but where we were. Exeunt.

DIV2.HEAD: SCENE VII. Clara's Apartment.

SP.P: Into what a World of Misfortunes does this false and inconsistent Notion of Honour plunge Men?

If they wou'd reflect on the Consequence. But why, why are we perplexing our selves, with the Event, before we know the Cause? Perhaps one of 'em has been to blame, and Honour was really con∣cern'd in the Affair.
Alas, be how it will, my Heart will never be at Peace.

DIV1.HEAD: AIR XXX. Thy vain Pursuit, fond Youth, &c.
DIV1.L: No Comfort e'er will Clara know,
'Till Death shall close these weeping Eyes:
There's nothing left worth Thought below;
My Life and Soul all bleeding lies.
Fly hence, begone all Thoughts of Joy,
Nor can ev'n Fate my Woes destroy.

SP.P: My wretched State is never to be reliev'd. Ho∣nour shou'd guard the Passage to my Heart, but Love is still the stronger.

DIV1.HEAD: AIR XXXI. Bush of Boon Traquare.
DIV1.L: In vain to guard my Breast I try,
The Tyrant Love subdues me;
And when I would the Charmer fly,
His winged Shaft pursues me.
My bleeding Heart must ever mourn;
The cruel Swain disdains me;
My Love he ever pays with Scorn,
And thinks not how it pains me. Weeps.

SP.P: I can have no Remedy but Death: If Moody is no more, I'll wander o'er the World, 'till I am lost for ever.

DIV1.HEAD: AIR XXXII. Since Celia's my Foe.
DIV1.L: Since Love is my Foe,
To the Groves I will go,
Where ever, for ever,
I'll sigh out my Woe.
Each Bird on the Tree
Attentive shall be,
And Sorrow shall borrow,
By looking on me.
The Hill and the Dale
Shall eccho my Wail,
And never, no never
Shall Lover prevail.
Since the False one is gone,
I'll sigh all alone,
Sit pining, declining,
Till Death ends my Moan.

SP.P: What, always Complaining! Come, dry up your Tears.

DIV1.HEAD: AIR XXXIII. Sawney was tall.
DIV1.L: Sorrow kills your blooming Charms:
Fill your Eyes with ev'ry Grace;
Mirth and Joy are Lovers Arms,
The pointed Dart's a smiling Face.
Cupid yet has Joys in store;
Faithful Love will meet Reward:
Dry those Eyes, and weep no more;
Since Love and Hymen are your Guard.

SP.P: What dost thou mean?

I'll tell you. I got from my old Master as soon as ever I cou'd, to undeceive you—but to do it in a Word, your Lovers are both safe and well: they have no Wounds but what Love has made, and you can cure. It was necessary I shou'd amuse your Father with the Story, in order to carry on a Design we have upon him, and I cou'd not do it without making you Parties.
Thou art an unaccountable Girl.

But wholly devoted to your Service. Your Lover, and yours too Madam, will be here in the Evening; and what wou'd you say, if your Father shou'd send for the very Parson to marry you to 'em? This Letter is from Moody, and will, I doubt not, sa∣tisfy you in other Particulars that won't be disagreeable.
You have rais'd us from Death, to live again.

Nay, you are not to discover your Knowlege of the Matter; if you do, our Plot's spoil'd; and I wou'd not have it so for my own sake: I have more Dependance upon it than you may imagine, I have a Golden Mine to spring in it.

DIV1.HEAD: AIR XXXIV. Peggy I must love thee.
DIV1.L: Some Mortals sing in Bacchus' Strain,
Of Love the wanton Lasses,
But Plutus only gives me Pain,
His Heat their Fire surpasses.
To him my Hopes and Wishes bend,
To him my Heart surrenders;
Possest of him, you gain a Friend,
And want no more Defenders.

SP.P: Dear Girl, in this Letter I have all I wisht— how came the blest Event?
Hush, your Father!

DIV2.STAGE: Enter Dalton, Prim, Clotpole, and Varole.

SP.P: Come Gentlemen, here are my Daughters, and you have my Consent too—make the best you can of 'em.
Which won't be a great deal, I believe.
Does the Plot take with 'em? To Lucy.
Beyond your Wishes—they snapt at the Bait as a Pike wou'd at a Gudgeon, and made no more Bones on't.

Thou art a lovely Creature surely: thy Comliness doth move the Spirit, which is the inward Light, towards thee: Nor is the outward Man un∣mov'd, but yerneth, and doth pant, as it were, to embrace thee, that of twain we may become one Flesh —fast bound, entwin'd together, locked in the Lock which is called Wedlock, hum!
Well said! to her!

DIV1.HEAD: AIR XXXV. Quakers Wedding.

SP.L: Humh, on a Friend, look kind, ah!
Humh! is to her inclin'd ah!
Wou'd she bid the Quaker take her,
Mate for Life to make her,

SP.P: Gad, you ha' done your Business, I can tell you. She says she likes you.
Doth she say so?
She does, but Mum!
Yea, Mum.
Only take care of Humming and Hawing too much, that's the only way to kill your Hopes.

DIV1.HEAD: AIR XXXVI. Lord, what's come to my Mother.
DIV1.L: When you launch out in Courting,
And would with Females be sporting,
With Hums and Haws, and distorting,
You'll never sail to the Port.
But if a Woman's Heart you'd win,
With Life and Spirit move,
'Tis that way you please 'em;
Your Canting will teize 'em;
This, this is the way to Love.

SP.P: You speaka de trute, pret Metress Lucy: Mon∣sieur hum, ha! you know noting, morbleu, noting at all—Letta me come.

DIV1.HEAD: AIR XXXVII. Ye Beaux of Pleasure.
DIV1.L: I'm of de Nation
Do teach de Fashion,
Vid Application,
De Song and Dance.
Sure dat will move you,
Beside me love you,
And to improve you,
Me come from France.

SP.P: Clara likes no body but you.
Dat is ver vel, prette Mrs. Lucy.
Poor Insignificant Wretches! do you ima∣gine you shall succeed before a Man of—Taste, and of Parts—and—Father-in-law, what wou'd you have me say to her?
Courage! Courage!
Madam, I have been Captain of the Militia several Years, and have behav'd with Courage and Conduct, in the greatest Dangers—a hem!

DIV1.HEAD: AIR XXXVIII. As Tipling John.
DIV1.L: If you did see
My Men and me,
All arm'd with Sword and Gun,
Walk up the Street,
Our Foes to meet,
You'd Swear we ne'er wou'd run.
In yonder Field
I made 'em yield,
And tremble at my Ire.
I'd have you think,
I scorn to wink,
When e'er my Soldiers fire.

DIV1.HEAD: AIR XXXIX. Hark, hark, the Cock Crows.

SP.L: Among your own Tribe shou'd be canting.
Wou'd to thee be a Bride,
Tho' People for Nations were wanting.
I resolv'd to be cloister'd a Nun first.

SP.P: To the end of the World we wou'd run first. Exe.
Obstinate Baggages!—now they expect to meet their young Coxcombs, ha.

They do—Mr. Prim, what she just now said, was only the want of Resolution—she did not care to declare her Mind in publick—but I have often heard her say privately, she lik'd no Peo∣ple in the World so well as Quakers—you may make her one.

Verily I do conceive thou utterest the Word of Truth. For as I did rest my Head upon my Bolster, in the Night, lo in the Darkness of the Night, the Light said unto me—Aminidab arise, go thou to the Damsel whom thou lovest, and she will turn unto thee; and thou shalt put unto her the Truth, and her Heart shall be towards thee; and the Friends shall rejoice therefore.
Captain, has not my Master told you the Se∣cret?
No.
Go to him, he knows her very Heart— she loves you to Distraction.
Ay!
Hark ye, Lucy.

You shall take Mr. Prim, and the Captain, into the Parlor, and prepare 'em for the Parson, he's waiting for that purpose already—When I have sent Varole about his Business, I'll to the Ladies, and prepare them, and give you Notice when all's ready.
I understand you—Hark ye Gentlemen— I wou'd beg three Words with you in private.

Mr. Varole, you see the old Gentleman is determined to prefer those two before you—but I know the young Lady likes you a great deal better than the Captain, and if you approve of it, I wou'd put you in a way to Circumvent him, and carry the Lady yourself.
Vid all mine Heart, me sal be ver glad.

Do you go before, I'll follow you immedi∣ately; it will not be proper for us to be seen toge∣ther. [Ex. Var.] In my Conscience there's no Merit in succeeding in my Design upon such Coxcombs as these—but now I think on't, the wisest Man turns Fool when he commences Lover.

DIV1.HEAD: AIR XL. Excuse me.
DIV1.L: When blind Love begins to move
The Heart of a poor sighing Lover,
The Wretch must dispense
With Reason and Sense,
'Tis Treason his Wits to recover.
If you feel the Dart,
Fixt within your Heart,
Struggling will prove vain, Sir;
Submission is all you have to please,
'Tis Love alone can give you Ease,
Your Striving helps the fond Disease,
And gives you greater Pain, Sir.

SP.P: This Maid of ours is an Excellent Wench at Invention. But how she'll bring herself off at last, I am at a loss to know.
Her Management has hitherto been so good, that I am in no great Pain about it.
She has indeed serv'd us beyond our Hopes— I shall never forget the Obligation, let the Conse∣quence to herself be what it will.
I cou'd wish tho' our Lovers wou'd appear; 'tis now the Hour appointed.
I don't doubt in the least, their being Pun∣ctual.
Here they are.
My Flora!
My dear Clara!
Can you forgive the Wrong I have done to Love and you, and take me to your Bosom?
Your Penitence will demand Forgiveness.

But as a Proof of it, and to put you both to the Test, let me tell you, there waits a Person hard by, who is the properest Man in the World to take your Confession, and who only can give you Abso∣lution.
I am ready to attend my Love.
And I.
Now indeed, you give us the greatest Proof of Sincerity.

SP.L: This is the fairest Hour of both our Lives;

SP.P: We the Happy Wives.
We the Happy Wives.

DIV2.HEAD: SCENE IX. A Hall.

SP.P: All goes exceeding Right, if nothing Inter∣poses to spoil the finishing Part—The Success of this Day, I fear, will make me hang my self for Joy; all the Parties are together; now's the Crisis, and no less than 4000 l. the Reward of my Labour.

DIV1.HEAD: AIR XLI. Abbot of Canterbury.
DIV1.L: 'Tis Money o'ercomes all our Griefs and our Cares,
It brings us Content, and dispells all our Fears.
It secures you a Friend, if a Friend you should need,
For Money a Thief from the Noose shall be freed.
Sing, hey down, down, derry down.

SP.P: Verily, this is now my Help-mate; the Light hath prevail'd, and she needeth not be asham'd of her Blushes.
Nor of her Husband—Come Daughter, unmask, let me salute thee, and give thee Joy.
Ten thousand Thanks to you, Sir. Unmasks.
What the Devil do I see?
I cou'd wish my self Blind; I am betrothed to Disgrace surely, and Shame will be my Portion.
Hope the best; I'll promise you for my fu∣ture Life to play you no idle Pranks, if you'll forgive the past.
I say No, I may not.
Oons, you Baggage, what's the Meaning of all this?
Matrimony, Sir, that's all.
I'll be the Death of thee.
I do hope thou wilt.
Look you, Sir, I am none of your Servant now.
Thou art the Devil's Servant.
If you call Names, my Husband shall demand—
I demand nothing sincerely—if it pleaseth him, he may Chastise thee.

DIV2.STAGE: Enter Clotpole, with Varole in Womens Clothes.

SP.P: Since my little Dear has giv'n me this Proof of her Love, it will be Folly to conceal it any longer. Come now, Father-in-Law, you may wish me Joy.
Ouy sans doubt.
How!
Zouns, more Tricks!
Who a Plague have I marry'd? the great Grandmother of the Witch of Endor—What are you? and who are you? and how the Devil came I by you?
These Questions will soon answer themselves —here are the Parties who shall clear up all.

DIV2.STAGE: Enter Edgar, Moody, Flora, and Clara.

SP.P: Now, Sir, your Blessing is all we want.
Edgar! O thou damn'd Jade! are these the wounded Duelists I had no more to be afraid of?
Why really, Sir, it so happens—they have no Wound but what Love can cure.
I shall run mad—Oons, I'll go set Fire to my House, lock up my Doors, and burn you all together. Exit.
Was ever Man so cheated? My only Comfort is, my Trapes here proves no Wife. Monsieur Varole, the best thing we can do, is to move off for fear we shou'd be burnt, as the old Gentleman threatens.
Vid all mine Heart—Begar m be sheated; me marry the Captain to prevent him marry Madam Clara, and Madam have marry anoder Person— Metress Lucy, begar you be une Jilt.

Look ye, Gentlemen, I was in the Secret of your purchasing these Ladies at Two thousand Pounds each, and thought I cou'd not too much expose you for it—I had no View in imposing on you, but to make you Witnesses of my Marriage with this Gen∣tleman; and to shew you in the most ridiculous Light I cou'd, and for fear you might have interpos'd the mean while, to prevent these more proper Lovers taking Possession of their own.
Ingenious Girl!
I'll home, and meditate Revenge. Exit.
Begar, and me too.

What thou hast done for us, deserves much more than Thanks—If Mr. Edgar pleases, and in order to make Mr. Prim easy, and satisfy'd with his Wife, we'll each advance Mrs. Lucy Five hundred Pounds as a Fortune.
She deserves a better Present; but that she shall have.
We are her Debtors too.
And for her Character, we'll answer, if Wit, Good-nature, and Virtue have any Merit, the Girl is worth his Acceptance.
Ladies and Gentlemen, I am infinitely oblig'd to you.
I know no other Remedy, on Condition she will turn unto the Light—for she is not uncomely —she hath Temptations—Wilt thou listen unto the Word of Soberness?
I will, truly.
Then truly I will take the Thousand Pounds and thee.
I thank thee lovingly.

DIV1.HEAD: AIR XLII. Among the Pure ones all.
DIV1.L: Among your Sect we see
The Women inspir'd will preach,
And therefore I will agree,
Because, in my Turn, I'll Teach.
Such Opinions sure
Must needs be pure,
That leave us the Tongue at Will.
For most you find
Are well inclin'd
That Weapon should ne'er lye still.

SP.P: All we have now to do, is to appease my Father.
Time, and our Submission, I hope will do it.
Well, foreseeing this good End, I have pro∣vided a Dance to entertain you.

DIV1.HEAD: AIR XLIII. Shepherd, when thou seest me fly.

SP.L: Our gloomy Woes are now no more,
The beaten Bark has reach'd the Shore.
Free from Tempest, free from Cares,
Thus from Grief and Anguish freed,
Thus from Grief and Anguish freed,
Thus from Grief and Anguish freed,
Thus from Grief and Anguish freed,

SP.SPEAKER: Omn.
SP.P: Halcyon Days, &c.

DIV1.HEAD: ERRATA.
DIV1.P: P. 12. Air 14. after destroy read me; after enjoy read thee. p. 14. l. 5. for Imputations read Imputation.
